> “They did eat, they drank, they married wives, they were given in marriage, until the day that Noe entered into the ark, and the flood came, **and destroyed them all.**” (Luke 17:27)

Here Jesus turns the historical flood into a **warning sermon** about His own coming:  
ordinary life, spiritual blindness, then sudden, total judgment.

## 3. Ring 2 – Why the Flood Came, and What It Foreshadows

Ring 2 reveals **why** this terrible judgment was sent and how God dealt with Noah.

God had formed man “of the dust of the ground” and “breathed into his nostrils the breath of life” (Genesis 2:7). But in Noah’s day:

> “GOD saw that the wickedness of man was great in the earth, and that **every imagination of the thoughts of his heart was only evil continually**.” (Genesis 6:5)

> “And the LORD said, I will destroy man whom I have created from the face of the earth…” (Genesis 6:7)

> “The end of all flesh is come before me; for **the earth is filled with violence** through them; and, behold, I will destroy them with the earth.” (Genesis 6:13)

Yet God is not quick-tempered. He says:

> “My spirit shall not always strive with man… yet his days shall be an hundred and twenty years.” (Genesis 6:3)

This matches Peter’s testimony:

> “…the longsuffering of God **waited in the days of Noah**, while the ark was a preparing, wherein few, that is, eight souls were saved by water.” (1 Peter 3:20)

And Noah in that time is “a preacher of righteousness” (2 Peter 2:5). So before the waters fell, there were:

- God’s **Spirit striving** (Genesis 6:3),
- God’s **preaching through Noah** (2 Peter 2:5),
- God’s **longsuffering waiting** (1 Peter 3:20),
- and God’s **specific warning** (Genesis 6:17; 7:4).

But a day came when the warnings ended:

> “In the six hundredth year of Noah’s life… the same day were all the fountains of the great deep broken up, and the windows of heaven were opened” (Genesis 7:11).  
> “In the selfsame day entered Noah… into the ark…  
> And they that went in, went in male and female of all flesh, as God had commanded him: **and the LORD shut him in.**” (Genesis 7:13–16)

There is a decisive divine act: *the LORD shut him in*. The door of mercy, long open, is finally closed.

Jesus uses the same picture when He warns:

> “When once the master of the house is risen up, and **hath shut to the door**, and ye begin to stand without, and to knock at the door, saying, Lord, Lord, open unto us; and he shall answer and say unto you, I know you not whence ye are:” (Luke 13:25)

The flood story thus preaches what Jesus preaches:  
there is a day when the door shuts, and late religion cannot enter.

Ring 2 also lifts our eyes from the past flood to a future, greater upheaval:

> “…by the word of God the heavens were of old, and the earth standing out of the water and in the water…  
> But the heavens and the earth, which are now, by the same word are kept in store, **reserved unto fire against the day of judgment and perdition of ungodly men.**” (2 Peter 3:5,7)

The old world perished by water (3:6). The present world is reserved for **fire**. And:

> “The day of the Lord will come as a thief in the night…” (2 Peter 3:10)

That is exactly the note Jesus strikes in His preaching about His coming (cf. Matthew 24:39’s “knew not”).

## 4. Ring 3 – The Final Shaking and the Call to Holiness

Ring 3 broadens this even further to a full cosmic shaking.

Isaiah describes the earth under judgment:

> “Therefore hath the curse devoured the earth, and they that dwell therein are desolate… and few men left.” (Isaiah 24:6)  
> “The earth is utterly broken down, the earth is clean dissolved, the earth is moved exceedingly.” (Isaiah 24:19)

Amos, Micah, Nahum, and the Psalms describe creation melting and trembling:

> “…it shall rise up wholly like a flood; and shall be drowned, as by the flood of Egypt.” (Amos 9:5)

> “The mountains shall be molten under him, and the valleys shall be cleft, as wax before the fire…” (Micah 1:4)

> “The mountains quake at him, and the hills melt, and the earth is burned at his presence…” (Nahum 1:5)

> “The hills melted like wax at the presence of the LORD, at the presence of the Lord of the whole earth.” (Psalms 97:5)

Peter gathers this all up:

> “…the elements shall melt with fervent heat, the earth also and the works that are therein shall be burned up.  
> Seeing then that all these things shall be dissolved, **what manner of persons ought ye to be in all holy conversation and godliness**,  
> Looking for and hasting unto the coming of the day of God…” (2 Peter 3:10–12)

And John is given the final scene:

> “And I saw a great white throne, and him that sat on it, from whose face **the earth and the heaven fled away; and there was found no place for them.**” (Revelation 20:11)

In that light, the voice of Christ comes again:

> “Behold, I come as a thief. **Blessed is he that watcheth, and keepeth his garments**, lest he walk naked, and they see his shame.” (Revelation 16:15)

Notice how this matches the picture in Luke 17:

- People are absorbed with this life—“They did eat, they drank, they married…” (Luke 17:27; cf. 17:26).
- Like the rich man in Luke 12 who says, “Soul, thou hast much goods laid up for many years; take thine ease, eat, drink, and be merry” (Luke 12:19).
- But judgment falls suddenly, and only those who are *watching* and *ready* are blessed (Revelation 16:15).

## 5. So How Does This Relate to the “Sermon on the Mount”?

The Scriptures given do not take us directly to Matthew 5–7, but they do show us how the same Lord who preached the Sermon on the Mount *also* preached using Noah’s flood.

From these texts, we see that:

- The flood itself is a **sermon from God**: exposing human wickedness (Genesis 6:5), displaying His longsuffering (1 Peter 3:20), and then His sure judgment (Genesis 7:17–23).
- Noah is called “a preacher of righteousness” (2 Peter 2:5). His whole life and obedience proclaimed what God would later make explicit in His own preaching: God requires righteousness.
- Jesus draws directly on this history in His preaching about His coming: people were busy, indifferent, and “knew not until the flood came” (Matthew 24:39). “So shall also the coming of the Son of man be.”
- The apostles then extend that warning: as surely as the old world perished by water (2 Peter 3:6), this present world will face a final judgment by fire (2 Peter 3:7,10), calling us to “all holy conversation and godliness” (2 Peter 3:11).

So when you read the Sermon on the Mount, with its call to true righteousness and a life that will stand in the day of testing, this flood narrative and its echoes are the backdrop.  

The message running through all these passages is the same:

- God’s patience is real, but not endless (Genesis 6:3; 1 Peter 3:20).
- Judgment is certain and often sudden (Genesis 7:11–12; Matthew 24:39; Luke 17:27; 2 Peter 3:10).
- Outward normality is no proof of safety; men can be eating, drinking, marrying, building—and perishing (Luke 17:26–27; Luke 12:19).
- Blessed are those who heed God’s word **now**, enter His appointed refuge while the door is open (Genesis 7:16; Luke 13:25), and live in watchful holiness (2 Peter 3:11–12; Revelation 16:15).

Thus, the flood in Genesis 7, the warnings of Jesus in Matthew 24 and Luke 17, the apostolic teaching in Peter, and the final visions in Revelation all preach a united sermon:  

Hear God’s word, turn from ungodliness, live in holiness and watchfulness—  
for the same Lord who once covered the mountains with water will again shake heaven and earth, and only those who are “in” His provision will stand.

> “And Jesus went about all Galilee, **teaching in their synagogues**, and **preaching the gospel of the kingdom**, and **healing all manner of sickness and all manner of disease among the people**.” (Matthew 4:23)

Three things stand together:

1. **Teaching** – in the synagogues (the regular gathering places for Scripture and instruction; cf. Psalms 74:8).
2. **Preaching** – specifically “the gospel of the kingdom.”
3. **Healing** – “all manner of sickness and all manner of disease.”

This pattern is repeated later:

> “And Jesus went about all the cities and villages, **teaching** in their synagogues, and **preaching the gospel of the kingdom**, and **healing every sickness and every disease among the people**.” (Matthew 9:35)  

So when the Sermon on the Mount begins in chapter 5, it is not an isolated lecture. It is the **authoritative teaching of the same One who is already displaying the power of the kingdom** in both word and deed.

### Healing and Forgiving: God at Work in Christ

What kind of healing is this? Scripture links it with **God’s own work**:

> “Who forgiveth all thine iniquities; **who healeth all thy diseases**;” (Psalms 103:3)  
> “He sent his word, and healed them, and delivered them from their destructions.” (Psalms 107:20)  
> “He healeth the broken in heart, and bindeth up their wounds.” (Psalms 147:3)

In the Gospels, this healing is tied directly to Jesus’ mission and to prophecy:

> “When the even was come, they brought unto him many that were possessed with devils: and he cast out the spirits with his word, and **healed all that were sick**:  
> That it might be fulfilled which was spoken by Esaias the prophet, saying, **Himself took our infirmities, and bare our sicknesses**.” (Matthew 8:16–17)

Isaiah had foretold this ministry:

> “The Spirit of the Lord GOD is upon me; because the LORD hath anointed me to **preach good tidings unto the meek**; he hath sent me to **bind up the brokenhearted**, to proclaim liberty to the captives, and the opening of the prison to them that are bound;” (Isaiah 61:1)

Jesus applies this to Himself:

> “The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because he hath anointed me to **preach the gospel to the poor**; he hath sent me to **heal the brokenhearted**, to preach deliverance to the captives, and recovering of sight to the blind, to **set at liberty them that are bruised**,” (Luke 4:18)

So when Matthew 4:24 says:

> “they brought unto him all sick people that were taken with divers diseases and torments, and those which were possessed with devils… and he healed them.” (Matthew 4:24)

we are seeing the **fulfillment of God’s promises**: the Lord who “healeth thee” (Exodus 15:26), who “healeth the broken in heart” (Psalms 147:3), is now at work in His Christ.

And much more than physical healing is in view:

> “Son, be of good cheer; **thy sins be forgiven thee**.” (Matthew 9:2)  
> “Wherefore I say unto thee, **Her sins, which are many, are forgiven**… And he said unto her, Thy sins are forgiven…. Thy faith hath saved thee; go in peace.” (Luke 7:47–50)

The One who teaches in Matthew 5 is the One who brings **both forgiveness and healing**.

## 2. The Message: “The Gospel of the Kingdom” and Repentance

Matthew 4:23 calls Jesus’ message “the gospel of the kingdom.” Just before this, Matthew summarizes that message:

> “From that time Jesus began to preach, and to say, **Repent: for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.**” (Matthew 4:17)

This echoes John the Baptist:

> “And saying, **Repent ye: for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.**” (Matthew 3:2)

And it matches how the Gospel of Mark sums up Jesus’ preaching:

> “Jesus came into Galilee, **preaching the gospel of the kingdom of God**,  
> And saying, **The time is fulfilled, and the kingdom of God is at hand: repent ye, and believe the gospel.**” (Mark 1:14–15)

Later, Jesus sends His disciples out with **the same kingdom message**:

> “And as ye go, preach, saying, **The kingdom of heaven is at hand.** Heal the sick, cleanse the lepers, raise the dead, cast out devils: freely ye have received, freely give.” (Matthew 10:7–8)  
> “And he sent them to **preach the kingdom of God, and to heal the sick**.” (Luke 9:2)  
> “And heal the sick that are therein, and say unto them, **The kingdom of God is come nigh unto you.**” (Luke 10:9–11)

So the Sermon on the Mount is **kingdom preaching**. It tells us **who really belongs to this kingdom**, and what kind of people are “blessed” in God’s sight.

Entry into that kingdom is tied to **repentance**—a turning to God with sorrow over sin:

> “For **godly sorrow worketh repentance to salvation** not to be repented of: but the sorrow of the world worketh death.” (2 Corinthians 7:10)  
> “I am not come to call the righteous, but **sinners to repentance**.” (Matthew 9:13)  
> “And that **repentance and remission of sins** should be preached in his name among all nations, beginning at Jerusalem.” (Luke 24:47)

This background is vital as Jesus begins His Sermon by pronouncing **blessing** on certain people.

## 3. The Audience and the Mountain (Matthew 4:25–5:2)

Because of His teaching, preaching, and healing, **great crowds** gather:

> “And there followed him great multitudes of people from Galilee, and from Decapolis, and from Jerusalem, and from Judaea, and from beyond Jordan.” (Matthew 4:25)

Then:

> “And seeing the multitudes, he went up into a mountain: and when he was set, **his disciples came unto him**:  
> And he opened his mouth, and **taught them**, saying…” (Matthew 5:1–2)

So:

- The **multitudes** draw the scene.
- But **He addresses His disciples** directly.

Luke describes a parallel setting where people come “to hear him, and to be healed of their diseases” (Luke 6:17), then:

> “And he lifted up his eyes on **his disciples**, and said, **Blessed be ye poor: for yours is the kingdom of God.**” (Luke 6:20)

Thus, the Sermon on the Mount (and its parallel in Luke 6) is especially directed to **those who follow Him**, but in the hearing of the crowds.

## 4. The First Beatitude: “Blessed are the poor in spirit” (Matthew 5:3)

> “Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.” (Matthew 5:3)

Luke’s parallel:

> “Blessed be ye poor: for yours is the kingdom of God.” (Luke 6:20)

The phrase “poor in spirit” is explained by many Scriptures that describe the kind of heart God regards:

> “but to this man will I look, even to him that is **poor and of a contrite spirit**, and trembleth at my word.” (Isaiah 66:2)  
> “The LORD is nigh unto them that are of a **broken heart**; and saveth such as be of a **contrite spirit**.” (Psalms 34:18)  
> “The sacrifices of God are a **broken spirit**: a broken and a contrite heart, O God, thou wilt not despise.” (Psalms 51:17)  
> “For thus saith the high and lofty One… I dwell in the high and holy place, **with him also that is of a contrite and humble spirit**, to revive the spirit of the humble, and to revive the heart of the contrite ones.” (Isaiah 57:15)

The **“poor in spirit”** are those who:

- Know their spiritual need.
- Are humbled, broken, contrite before God.
- Tremble at His word, rather than trusting in their own righteousness.

We see an example in Jesus’ parable:

> “And the publican, standing afar off, would not lift up so much as his eyes unto heaven, but smote upon his breast, saying, **God be merciful to me a sinner.**” (Luke 18:13)

Such a person is spiritually “poor,” yet **this** is the one God receives. Jesus says of them:

> “for **theirs is the kingdom of heaven**.” (Matthew 5:3)

This matches so many of His later statements:

> “Verily I say unto you, That the publicans and the harlots go into the kingdom of God before you.” (Matthew 21:31)  

Why? Because when they heard John and Jesus, **they repented** (Matthew 21:31–32), whereas the proud religious leaders did not.

So the Sermon on the Mount begins by **overturning worldly ideas of who is “blessed.”** Not the self-satisfied religious, but the spiritually needy who come to God in humility.

## 5. The Second Beatitude: “Blessed are they that mourn” (Matthew 5:4)

> “Blessed are they that mourn: for they shall be comforted.” (Matthew 5:4)

Again, Luke sheds light:

> “Blessed are ye that weep now: for ye shall laugh.” (Luke 6:21)  
> “Woe unto you that laugh now! for ye shall mourn and weep.” (Luke 6:25)

This mourning is not merely natural sorrow, but fits with:

- **Godly sorrow** leading to repentance (2 Corinthians 7:10).
- The broken-hearted whom the Lord heals (Psalms 147:3; Isaiah 61:1).
- Those turning back to God under His chastening:

> “Come, and let us return unto the LORD: for he hath torn, and he will heal us; he hath smitten, and he will bind us up.” (Hosea 6:1)  
> “I have seen his ways, and will heal him: I will lead him also, and **restore comforts unto him and to his mourners**.” (Isaiah 57:18)

The Lord is near such people:

> “The LORD is nigh unto them that are of a broken heart…” (Psalms 34:18)

Jesus says they “shall be comforted.” This comfort includes:

- **Present healing and forgiveness** (as seen in His ministry: Matthew 9:2; Luke 7:47–50).
- **Future joy and reward**:

  > “Rejoice ye in that day, and leap for joy: for, behold, your **reward is great in heaven**…” (Luke 6:23)  
  > “Rejoice, and be exceeding glad: for **great is your reward in heaven**: for so persecuted they the prophets which were before you.” (Matthew 5:12)  
  > “For our light affliction, which is but for a moment, worketh for us a far more exceeding and **eternal weight of glory**;” (2 Corinthians 4:17)

Thus, those who **mourn now**—over sin, over suffering for Christ, over the broken condition of this world—are promised deep, certain comfort from God.

## 6. Blessing and Woe: The Great Reversal (Luke 6:20–26)

Luke’s parallel teaching makes the contrast explicit:

> “Blessed be ye poor: for yours is the kingdom of God.  
> Blessed are ye that hunger now: for ye shall be filled. Blessed are ye that weep now: for ye shall laugh.  
> Blessed are ye, when men shall hate you… for the Son of man’s sake. Rejoice ye in that day… for, behold, your reward is great in heaven…” (Luke 6:20–23)

But then:

> “But woe unto you that are rich! for ye have received your consolation.  
> Woe unto you that are full! for ye shall hunger.  
> Woe unto you that laugh now! for ye shall mourn and weep.  
> Woe unto you, when all men shall speak well of you! for so did their fathers to the false prophets.” (Luke 6:24–26)

This shines light back on the Sermon on the Mount:

- Those who appear **blessed now**—rich, full, laughing, praised—may face future **woe**, if their hearts are not poor, repentant, and obedient to God.
- Those who **suffer now**—poor, hungry, weeping, hated for Christ’s sake—are **truly blessed**, with great reward in heaven.

This matches Jesus’ word:

> “Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness’ sake: for **theirs is the kingdom of heaven**.” (Matthew 5:10)  
> “Rejoice, and be exceeding glad: for **great is your reward in heaven**: for so persecuted they the prophets which were before you.” (Matthew 5:12)  
> “But rejoice, inasmuch as ye are **partakers of Christ’s sufferings**; that, when his glory shall be revealed, **ye may be glad also with exceeding joy**.” (1 Peter 4:13)

So the Sermon on the Mount sets forth a **heavenly estimation** of blessing—completely different from man’s.

## 7. True Righteousness vs. Hypocrisy

Within this larger sermon, Jesus also exposes false religion. One glimpse of this is:

> “And when thou prayest, thou shalt not be as the **hypocrites** are: for they love to pray **standing in the synagogues and in the corners of the streets, that they may be seen of men**. Verily I say unto you, They have their reward.” (Matthew 6:5)

This agrees with His later rebuke:

> “But woe unto you, scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! for ye **shut up the kingdom of heaven against men**: for ye neither go in yourselves, neither suffer ye them that are entering to go in.” (Matthew 23:13)

The Sermon on the Mount, from the very first Beatitudes, draws a line between:

- **The humble, broken, repentant**, who are truly blessed and have the kingdom.
- **The proud, outwardly religious, self-confident**, who are warned of woe, exclusion, and judgment.

Again, Jesus says publicans and harlots go into the kingdom before the religious leaders, because the former **repented** (Matthew 21:31–32), while the latter “repented not.”

## 8. The Golden Thread: The Sermon’s Place in God’s Plan

Pulling the strands together:

- In the Old Testament, God repeatedly shows regard for **the poor and contrite in spirit**, the brokenhearted, those who mourn and return to Him (Psalms 34:18; 51:17; 57:15; 147:3; Isaiah 57:15,18; 61:1; 66:2; Hosea 6:1).
- He promises to **heal**, to **bind up**, to **comfort**.
- Jesus comes preaching, “Repent: for the kingdom of heaven is at hand” (Matthew 4:17), healing all manner of sickness and disease, forgiving sins, fulfilling Isaiah’s promises.
- Great multitudes follow; He goes up into a mountain, His disciples come to Him, and He **begins His Sermon** with these words:
  - “Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.” (Matthew 5:3)
  - “Blessed are they that mourn: for they shall be comforted.” (Matthew 5:4)
- Luke’s parallel adds the balancing **woes** and underscores that the real dividing line is not outward condition but **heart posture toward God and His Son** (Luke 6:20–26).

This same message continues after His resurrection:

> “And that **repentance and remission of sins** should be preached in his name **among all nations**…” (Luke 24:47)  

And heaven rejoices when this happens:

> “joy shall be in heaven over **one sinner that repenteth**…” (Luke 15:7,10)

## Conclusion

The Sermon on the Mount begins with the King of heaven, already preaching and demonstrating **the gospel of the kingdom**, sitting down to teach His disciples what kind of people are truly **blessed**.

According to Jesus:

- The **poor in spirit**—the contrite, broken, spiritually needy—are blessed, for **theirs is the kingdom of heaven**.
- Those who **mourn now**—in godly sorrow, in suffering, in faithfulness to Him—are blessed, for **they shall be comforted**.
- Those who are **persecuted for righteousness’ sake** and for the Son of man’s sake are blessed, for **their reward is great in heaven**.

This sermon perfectly matches the whole witness of Scripture: God draws near to the contrite, heals the brokenhearted, calls sinners to repentance, and promises eternal comfort and glory to those who suffer with Christ.

The Sermon on the Mount, therefore, is **the King’s description of the citizens of His kingdom**—people marked not by outward success, but by inward humility, repentance, and a hope fixed on the reward “in heaven” that He Himself gives.

## 4. “Blessed are they that mourn” – Godly sorrow and divine comfort

And of those whom God has wounded, and then heals:

> “Come, and let us return unto the LORD: for **he hath torn, and he will heal us**; he hath smitten, and he will bind us up.” (Hosea 6:1)  
> “For he maketh sore, and bindeth up: **he woundeth, and his hands make whole**.” (Job 5:18)

The prophets also link mourning with those God will comfort:

> “I have seen his ways, and **will heal him**: I will lead him also, and **restore comforts unto him and to his mourners**.” (Isaiah 57:18)

And again:

> “He healeth the **broken in heart**, and bindeth up their wounds.” (Psalm 147:3)

This “mourning” is the grief of those who:

- Are broken over their sin,  
- Are burdened under affliction,  
- Cry to the LORD in their trouble (Psalm 107:19–20).

Such mourners are **blessed**, Jesus says, “for they shall be comforted.” That comfort comes:

1. **Now**, through forgiveness and peace with God:  
   - “Son, be of good cheer; **thy sins be forgiven thee**.” (Matthew 9:2)  
   - “Her sins, which are many, **are forgiven**… And he said unto her, **Thy faith hath saved thee; go in peace**.” (Luke 7:47–50)

2. **In the world to come**, through joy and glory:  
   - “Rejoice ye in that day, and leap for joy: for, behold, **your reward is great in heaven**…” (Luke 6:23)  
   - “Rejoice, and be exceeding glad: for **great is your reward in heaven**…” (Matthew 5:12)  
   - “For our **light affliction**, which is but for a moment, worketh for us a **far more exceeding and eternal weight of glory**;” (2 Corinthians 4:17)  
   - “…when his glory shall be revealed, ye may be glad also **with exceeding joy**.” (1 Peter 4:13)

So the second beatitude declares: **those who truly grieve in a godly way—over sin and suffering, drawing them to God—will have the deep comfort of His healing, forgiveness, and final joy.**

---

## 5. Miracles and Message Together – The Kingdom in Word and Power

The sermon on the mount is not a bare moral code. It stands in the midst of Jesus’ **kingdom preaching and healing**.

Everywhere He goes, He does the same:

> “Now when the sun was setting, **all they that had any sick with divers diseases brought them unto him**; and he laid his hands on every one of them, and healed them.” (Luke 4:40)  
> “And Jesus went forth, and saw a great multitude, and **was moved with compassion toward them, and he healed their sick**.” (Matthew 14:14)

He then sends His disciples to do likewise:

> “And as ye go, preach, saying, **The kingdom of heaven is at hand**. **Heal the sick**, cleanse the lepers, raise the dead, cast out devils: freely ye have received, freely give.” (Matthew 10:7–8)  
> “And he sent them to **preach the kingdom of God, and to heal the sick**.” (Luke 9:2)  
> “And heal the sick that are therein, and say unto them, **The kingdom of God is come nigh unto you**.” (Luke 10:9)

The miracles are visible signs that:

- The King is present,  
- The promised time has arrived:  
  > “The law and the prophets were until John: since that time **the kingdom of God is preached**, and every man presseth into it.” (Luke 16:16)

But His greater work is **forgiveness and repentance**:

> “…I am not come to call the righteous, but **sinners to repentance**.” (Matthew 9:13)  
> “And that **repentance and remission of sins** should be preached in his name among all nations, beginning at Jerusalem.” (Luke 24:47)

Thus the sermon on the mount begins by describing the kind of people who actually receive this kingdom salvation:

- **Poor in spirit** – contrite, humble, knowing their need.  
- **Mourning** – grieved in a godly way, turning to God.  
- Later in the same sermon:  
  > “Blessed are they which are **persecuted for righteousness’ sake**: for **theirs is the kingdom of heaven**.” (Matthew 5:10)  
  > “Rejoice, and be exceeding glad: for great is your reward in heaven: for so **persecuted they the prophets** which were before you.” (Matthew 5:12)

Luke matches this with:

> “Blessed are ye, when men shall **hate you**, and when they shall separate you… for the Son of man's sake. **Rejoice ye in that day**, and leap for joy: for, behold, your reward is great in heaven…” (Luke 6:22–23)

So from the start, the sermon on the mount shows that the truly blessed are those who, though lowly, sorrowing, and even persecuted, **receive the kingdom now and glory hereafter**.

---

## 6. In Summary: What This Portion of the Sermon on the Mount Teaches

Putting it together from these Scriptures:

1. **The context**: Jesus has been **preaching the gospel of the kingdom** and **healing** all manner of sickness (Matthew 4:23–25; 9:35), fulfilling God’s promises to heal and to bind up the brokenhearted (Psalm 103:3; Isaiah 61:1; Luke 4:18).

2. **The audience**: His **disciples** come to Him, with multitudes listening (Matthew 5:1–2; Luke 6:17,20). The sermon is teaching for those who would follow Him as King.

3. **The message**: The very first beatitudes declare who is truly “blessed” and who “has” the kingdom:
   - **“Blessed are the poor in spirit: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.”** (Matthew 5:3)  
   These are the humble, contrite, spiritually needy ones (Isaiah 66:2; Psalm 51:17; Luke 18:13) who respond to the call to **repent** as the kingdom draws near (Matthew 3:2; 4:17; Mark 1:15).
   - **“Blessed are they that mourn: for they shall be comforted.”** (Matthew 5:4)  
   These are those who grieve in **godly sorrow** (2 Corinthians 7:10), whose broken hearts God heals and to whom He restores comforts (Isaiah 57:15,18; Psalm 147:3). Their comfort is forgiveness now and eternal joy to come (Matthew 5:12; Luke 6:21–23; 2 Corinthians 4:17).

4. **The great reversal**: The poor, hungry, and weeping who look to God are blessed; those who are rich, full, and laughing now, but without repentance, face woe (Luke 6:20–25).

So, in this opening of the sermon on the mount, the Lord Jesus sets the tone for all that follows: **the kingdom of heaven belongs not to the self-righteous, but to the broken, repentant, lowly, and faithful—even when they suffer.** These are the ones whom God calls “blessed,” and to whom He promises His kingdom, His comfort, and His eternal reward.

Cain and Abel are the first children of Adam and Eve after the Fall. Their story shows what life looks like *outside* the garden, under the curse—and how two very different ways of relating to God appear almost immediately in human history.

I’ll walk through the passages in order, then show how the rest of Scripture (in the verses you provided) sheds light on them.

## 1. The world Cain and Abel were born into: driven from life

Before we meet Cain and Abel, the Bible shows us Adam and Eve cast out of Eden:

> “And the LORD God said, Behold, the man is become as one of us, to know good and evil: and now, **lest he put forth his hand, and take also of the tree of life, and eat, and live for ever**:  
> Therefore the LORD God **sent him forth from the garden of Eden**, to till the ground from whence he was taken.  
> So he drove out the man; and he placed at the east of the garden of Eden Cherubims, and a flaming sword… to keep the way of the tree of life.” (Genesis 3:22–24)

Earlier, God had commanded:

> “But of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, thou shalt not eat of it: **for in the day that thou eatest thereof thou shalt surely die**.” (Genesis 2:17)

After they eat, God says to Adam:

> “cursed is the ground for thy sake; in sorrow shalt thou eat of it all the days of thy life;  
> Thorns also and thistles shall it bring forth to thee…  
> In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread, till thou return unto the ground… for dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return.” (Genesis 3:17–19)

So, when Cain and Abel are born:

- Humanity **knows good and evil**, but is **separated from the tree of life** (Genesis 3:22).  
- The **ground is cursed**, work is hard, and death is certain (Genesis 3:17–19).  
- Man can no longer simply reach out and take eternal life by his own act (Genesis 3:22–24).

This is the world in which Cain and Abel appear.

---

## 2. Cain and Abel: sons of Adam, workers under the curse

Then we read:

> “And Adam knew Eve his wife; and she conceived, and bare Cain, and said, I have gotten a man from the LORD.  
> And she again bare his brother Abel. **And Abel was a keeper of sheep, but Cain was a tiller of the ground.**” (Genesis 4:1–2)

They are sons of Adam, who himself was created:

> “in the likeness of God made he him” (Genesis 5:1; cf. 1:26–27).

So Cain and Abel, as Adam’s sons, are part of humanity made in God’s image (Genesis 1:26–27; 5:1), now living east of Eden, under the curse.

Their occupations match the creation mandate:

> “Let us make man in our image… and let them have **dominion** over the fish… fowl… cattle… and over all the earth” (Genesis 1:26).  
> “Thou madest him to have **dominion over the works of thy hands**; thou hast put all things under his feet:  
> All sheep and oxen, yea, and the beasts of the field;  
> The fowl of the air, and the fish of the sea…” (Psalms 8:6–8).

Abel, “a keeper of sheep” (Genesis 4:2), exercises dominion over animals.  
Cain, “a tiller of the ground” (Genesis 4:2), works the earth.

Both callings are legitimate. Scripture honours both:

- God “causeth the grass to grow for the cattle, and herb for the service of man: that he may bring forth **food out of the earth**” (Psalms 104:14).  
- “Moreover **the profit of the earth is for all**: the king himself is served by the field.” (Ecclesiastes 5:9).

Yet Cain’s work is especially tied to the **cursed ground** (Genesis 3:17–18). Later, after his sin, God says to him:

> “When thou tillest the ground, **it shall not henceforth yield unto thee her strength**; a fugitive and a vagabond shalt thou be in the earth.” (Genesis 4:12)

So Cain’s entire life and identity are bound up with a ground already under curse, and then, because of his later sin, even more against him.

---

## 3. Their offerings: how they approach God

In that fallen world, both brothers bring offerings:

> “And in process of time it came to pass, that Cain brought of **the fruit of the ground** an offering unto the LORD.  
> And Abel, he also brought of **the firstlings of his flock and of the fat thereof**. And the LORD had respect unto Abel and to his offering.” (Genesis 4:3–4)

Notice a few plain points:

1. **Both** come to the LORD with offerings. Worship is still possible outside Eden.
2. Each brings what matches his calling:
   - Cain – “fruit of the ground”
   - Abel – “firstlings of his flock and of the fat thereof”
3. God’s evaluation is clear on one side:
   - “the LORD **had respect unto Abel and to his offering**” (Genesis 4:4).

Field work itself is not despised—Scripture says the earth’s profit is for all (Ecclesiastes 5:9). So the problem is not that Cain worked the soil.

But Abel’s offering is described as:

- “firstlings” – the first-born of the flock  
- “and of the fat thereof” – the richest part

So Abel brings the **first and the best** of what he has. His offering aligns with the spirit of the “meek” who seek the LORD:

> “The meek shall eat and be satisfied: **they shall praise the LORD that seek him: your heart shall live for ever.**” (Psalms 22:26)

Abel’s offering is joined to seeking and honouring God. God looks not only at the gift, but at the worshipper—“the LORD had respect unto Abel and to his offering” (Genesis 4:4).

By contrast, Scripture later shows that Cain’s life leads to judgment (Genesis 4:12, 25). His problem is not his trade, but his *heart and way* before God. This fits the broader witness of Scripture:

> “Lo, this only have I found, that God hath made man upright; **but they have sought out many inventions.**” (Ecclesiastes 7:29)

> “For thou hast trusted in thy wickedness… Thy wisdom and thy knowledge, it hath perverted thee…” (Isaiah 47:10)

Worldly wisdom and self-will twist the heart away from God. Abel comes in meek worship; Cain’s way becomes the opposite.

---

## 4. From disobedience to murder: sin growing in Adam’s race

The Fall began with a promise of false wisdom:

> “For God doth know that in the day ye eat thereof, then your eyes shall be opened, and **ye shall be as gods, knowing good and evil**.” (Genesis 3:5)

After eating, God Himself says:

> “Behold, the man is become as one of us, **to know good and evil**…” (Genesis 3:22)

So mankind **knows** good and evil, but that knowledge has not made him godly. Instead, it has led to exile, toil, and death.

Very soon that corruption shows itself in Cain. We are not given all the steps in the verses here, but we are told the outcome plainly:

> “…For God, said she, hath appointed me another seed instead of Abel, **whom Cain slew.**” (Genesis 4:25)

Cain becomes the first murderer in Scripture. And this is especially terrible because humans bear God’s image:

> “Whoso sheddeth man's blood, by man shall his blood be shed: **for in the image of God made he man.**” (Genesis 9:6)

Abel is not just killing “a person” in the abstract; he is killing one made in God’s image, a worshipper whose offering God accepted.

For that, Cain’s relationship to the ground—already cursed because of Adam—is further judged:

> “When thou tillest the ground, it shall not henceforth yield unto thee her strength; **a fugitive and a vagabond** shalt thou be in the earth.” (Genesis 4:12)

The soil that was meant to serve man (Psalms 104:14; Ecclesiastes 5:9) now refuses its strength to Cain. Creation itself testifies against his sin.

All this fits the wider pattern the Scriptures describe:

- People trust in their own wisdom, which God makes foolish:

  > “Where is the wise? … hath not God **made foolish the wisdom of this world?**  
  > For after that in the wisdom of God the world by wisdom knew not God…” (1 Corinthians 1:20–21)

  > “For the wisdom of this world is foolishness with God…” (1 Corinthians 3:19)

- People walk according to “the course of this world”:

  > “Wherein in time past ye walked according to the course of this world, according to the prince of the power of the air…  
  > Among whom also we all had our conversation in times past in the lusts of our flesh… and were by nature **the children of wrath**…” (Ephesians 2:2–3)

Cain is an early example of this path: knowing good and evil, yet walking in evil, even to the point of killing his brother.

## 5. Abel, Cain, and Seth: two ways and a preserved seed

After Abel’s death, Eve says:

> “For God, said she, hath appointed me **another seed instead of Abel, whom Cain slew.**” (Genesis 4:25)

Abel, the man whose offering God respected, is cut down. Yet God “appoints” another seed—Seth—to continue the line.

This fits God’s purpose for mankind:

- He made man in His likeness (Genesis 5:1; 1:26–27).
- Though man corrupts his way (Ecclesiastes 7:29), God remains the Maker and Potter:

  > “But now, O LORD, thou art our father; **we are the clay, and thou our potter**; and we all are the work of thy hand.” (Isaiah 64:8)  
  > “Know ye that the LORD he is God: **it is he that hath made us**, and not we ourselves; we are his people, and the sheep of his pasture.” (Psalms 100:3)

So in Abel and Cain we see two paths:

- Abel – meek, God-honouring worship; God “had respect unto Abel and to his offering” (Genesis 4:4).  
- Cain – goes on to murder his brother; becomes a fugitive and a vagabond (Genesis 4:12, 25).

In Seth, we see God preserving a **seed** despite sin: His purpose for a people who belong to Him will stand.

---

## 6. From the lost tree of life to the promised tree of life

Cain and Abel live in a world shut out from the tree of life:

> God “placed at the east of the garden of Eden Cherubims, and a flaming sword… **to keep the way of the tree of life**.” (Genesis 3:24)

Humans may not reach out and seize eternal life on their own terms.

But Revelation shows **the tree of life opened again**, not to all indiscriminately, but to those who come God’s way:

> “To him that overcometh will I give **to eat of the tree of life**, which is in the midst of the paradise of God.” (Revelation 2:7)

> “…on either side of the river, was there **the tree of life**, which bare twelve manner of fruits… and the leaves of the tree were for the healing of the nations.” (Revelation 22:2)

> “Blessed are they that do his commandments, **that they may have right to the tree of life**, and may enter in through the gates into the city.” (Revelation 22:14)

The contrast is sharp:

- In Genesis, man tries to take forbidden fruit (Genesis 3:6) and is then barred from the tree of life (Genesis 3:22–24).
- In Revelation, those who **overcome** and **do his commandments** are freely given the tree of life.

Psalms connects this with the heart posture of the meek:

> “The meek shall eat and be satisfied: they shall praise the LORD that seek him: **your heart shall live for ever.**” (Psalms 22:26)

Abel’s accepted offering, in meekness and seeking God, points toward this way of life from God’s hand—not seizing wisdom or life on our own terms (as in Genesis 3), but receiving what He gives to those who trust and obey.

Cain, on the other hand, stands in the line of those who follow the “course of this world” (Ephesians 2:2), whose wisdom God frustrates (Isaiah 44:25; 1 Corinthians 1:20), and who end in death.

---

## 7. Christ and the restoration of the image and life

At creation, man is made in God’s image (Genesis 1:26–27; 5:1). In Cain and Abel, that image-bearing humanity is already divided: one worshipper pleasing to God, the other a murderer.

The New Testament tells us that the true and perfect **image of God** is Christ:

> “the glorious gospel of Christ, **who is the image of God**…” (2 Corinthians 4:4)

And God works through Christ to renew His people:

> “For God, who commanded the light to shine out of darkness, hath shined in our hearts, **to give the light of the knowledge of the glory of God in the face of Jesus Christ.**” (2 Corinthians 4:6)

> “But we all, with open face beholding as in a glass the glory of the Lord, are **changed into the same image from glory to glory**, even as by the Spirit of the Lord.” (2 Corinthians 3:18)

> “For we are **his workmanship, created in Christ Jesus unto good works**, which God hath before ordained that we should walk in them.” (Ephesians 2:10)

What Adam lost, and what is so tragically twisted in Cain, is restored in Christ:

- We are made **new creations**, God’s workmanship.  
- We are changed back into God’s image in holiness.  
- We are set to walk, not in Cain’s works of wrath, but in “good works” (Ephesians 2:10).

Thus the call is:

> “…let them that suffer according to the will of God commit the keeping of their souls to him in well doing, **as unto a faithful Creator.**” (1 Peter 4:19)

Abel, though slain, represents those who entrust themselves to God and whose “heart shall live for ever” (Psalms 22:26). Cain represents those who, knowing good and evil, still choose evil.

---

## 8. Summary

Putting it all together from the Scriptures you provided:

- Cain and Abel are the first sons of Adam and Eve, born **outside Eden**, under the curse on the ground and the sentence of death (Genesis 3:17–19; 4:1–2).
- Both live out the creation mandate in different vocations: Abel over sheep, Cain over the ground (Genesis 4:2; Psalms 8:6–8).
- Both bring offerings, but **God has respect to Abel and to his offering**—he brings the first and the best of his flock, in a spirit that matches the meek who seek God (Genesis 4:3–4; Psalms 22:26).
- Cain later **kills Abel** (Genesis 4:25), shedding the blood of one made in God’s image (Genesis 9:6), and is further judged in his work with the earth (Genesis 4:12).
- Abel and Cain picture two ways: humble, God-honouring worship that leads to life from God, and self-willed, sinful life that leads to judgment.
- God preserves His purpose by appointing **another seed**, Seth, instead of Abel (Genesis 4:25), showing that His plan for a godly line will stand.
- Though the tree of life is barred in Genesis (Genesis 3:22–24), God promises access to it again in Revelation for those who overcome and keep His commandments (Revelation 2:7; 22:2,14).
- In Christ, the true image of God (2 Corinthians 4:4), God shines light into hearts and recreates a people in His image, to walk in good works instead of Cain’s way (2 Corinthians 3:18; 4:6; Ephesians 2:10).

So the story of Cain and Abel is an early, powerful picture of how fallen mankind responds to God: either like Abel, in meek, God-honouring worship that leads to life, or like Cain, in self-will and sin that ends in judgment. And it points us forward to Christ, the faithful image of God and the giver of access to the tree of life once more.

the passover

Passover in Scripture is first of all an act of God, then a yearly memorial, and finally a shadow pointing to Christ.

---

## 1. The first Passover: judgment and deliverance (Exodus 12)

In the anchor passage, the LORD Himself defines what Passover is and how it is to be kept.

They are to eat a lamb:

> “And they shall eat the flesh in that night, roast with fire, and unleavened bread; and with bitter herbs they shall eat it.” (Exodus 12:8)

Specific instructions are given:

- The lamb must be roasted with fire, not raw or boiled:
  > “Eat not of it raw, nor sodden at all with water, but roast with fire; his head with his legs, and with the purtenance thereof.” (12:9)
- Nothing must remain until morning; what is left must be burned:
  > “And ye shall let nothing of it remain until the morning; and that which remaineth of it until the morning ye shall burn with fire.” (12:10)

They must eat it ready to leave Egypt:

> “And thus shall ye eat it; with your loins girded, your shoes on your feet, and your staff in your hand; and ye shall eat it in haste: it is the LORD’S passover.” (12:11)

Why? Because the LORD is about to judge Egypt:

> “For I will pass through the land of Egypt this night, and will smite all the firstborn… and against all the gods of Egypt I will execute judgment: I am the LORD.” (12:12)

The protection from this judgment is the blood of the lamb:

> “And the blood shall be to you for a token upon the houses where ye are: and when I see the blood, I will pass over you, and the plague shall not be upon you to destroy you, when I smite the land of Egypt.” (12:13)

So:

- The destroyer goes through Egypt to kill the firstborn (Exodus 12:23).
- The LORD “will pass over the door, and will not suffer the destroyer to come in unto your houses to smite you” when He sees the blood (12:23).

This is why it is called “the LORD’s passover” (12:11): He passes over those under the blood.

God then makes that night a perpetual memorial:

> “And this day shall be unto you for a memorial; and ye shall keep it a feast to the LORD throughout your generations; ye shall keep it a feast by an ordinance for ever.” (Exodus 12:14)

---

## 2. The elements of Passover and what they remember

### Bitter herbs and bitter bondage

They ate the lamb “with bitter herbs” (Exodus 12:8). Earlier, Scripture says:

> “And they made their lives bitter with hard bondage…” (Exodus 1:14)

Deuteronomy connects the unleavened bread with suffering:

> “…seven days shalt thou eat unleavened bread therewith, even the bread of affliction; for thou camest forth out of the land of Egypt in haste…” (Deuteronomy 16:3)

So the bitter herbs and “bread of affliction” recall the bitterness of slavery in Egypt and the affliction Israel endured.

### Unleavened bread and haste

In the first Passover, they had to be ready to move:

> “ye shall eat it in haste” (Exodus 12:11).

Deuteronomy links this haste with unleavened bread:

> “…for thou camest forth out of the land of Egypt in haste: that thou mayest remember the day when thou camest forth…” (Deuteronomy 16:3)

Thus the feast of unleavened bread is tied to the exodus:

- “Seven days shall ye eat unleavened bread; even the first day ye shall put away leaven out of your houses” (Exodus 12:15).
- “Seven days shall there be no leaven found in your houses” (12:19).
- “Ye shall eat nothing leavened; in all your habitations shall ye eat unleavened bread.” (12:20)

This is expanded:

- “On the fifteenth day of the same month is the feast of unleavened bread unto the LORD: seven days ye must eat unleavened bread.” (Leviticus 23:6)
- “Thou shalt keep the feast of unleavened bread… for in it thou camest out from Egypt” (Exodus 23:15).
- “Observe the month of Abib, and keep the passover unto the LORD thy God: for in the month of Abib the LORD thy God brought thee forth out of Egypt by night.” (Deuteronomy 16:1)

So unleavened bread marks:

- The haste of leaving Egypt.
- The separation from their old life of bondage.

### The lamb without blemish and entirely consumed

The Passover lamb is specified:

> “Your lamb shall be without blemish, a male of the first year…” (Exodus 12:5)

It is kept until the 14th day and then killed:

> “…the whole assembly of the congregation of Israel shall kill it in the evening.” (Exodus 12:6; cf. Leviticus 23:5)

It must be roasted with fire, and none left until morning (Exodus 12:9–10). Later, God reaffirms:

- “Thou shalt not offer the blood of my sacrifice with leaven; neither shall the sacrifice of the feast of the passover be left unto the morning.” (Exodus 34:25)
- “And there shall… not… any thing of the flesh, which thou sacrificedst the first day at even, remain all night until the morning.” (Deuteronomy 16:4)
- “And thou shalt roast and eat it in the place which the LORD thy God shall choose: and thou shalt turn in the morning, and go unto thy tents.” (Deuteronomy 16:7)

This “same day” consumption parallels peace/thanksgiving offerings:

> “the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offerings for thanksgiving shall be eaten the same day… he shall not leave any of it until the morning.” (Leviticus 7:15)

So the lamb:

- Must be perfect (“without blemish”).
- Must be fully and promptly consumed.
- Is both a sacrifice and a meal shared by the redeemed.

---

## 3. Passover as covenant memorial and identity marker

Passover is more than a one-time event; it is bound up with God’s covenant promises.

God had told Abram:

> “…thy seed shall be a stranger in a land that is not theirs, and shall serve them; and they shall afflict them four hundred years.” (Genesis 15:13)

He also promised:

> “I will establish my covenant… to be a God unto thee, and to thy seed after thee. And I will give unto thee… all the land of Canaan, for an everlasting possession; and I will be their God.” (Genesis 17:7–8)

In Exodus, God connects the exodus (and thus Passover) to that promise:

> “And I will bring you in unto the land, concerning the which I did swear to give it to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob…” (Exodus 6:8)

So Passover is the night when God begins to bring His people out “of the house of bondage” (Exodus 20:2; 13:3) to the land He had sworn.

Because of this, Passover must be remembered:

- “And this day shall be unto you for a memorial…” (Exodus 12:14).
- “And it shall be for a sign unto thee upon thine hand, and for a memorial between thine eyes, that the LORD’S law may be in thy mouth: for with a strong hand hath the LORD brought thee out of Egypt.” (Exodus 13:9)
- “And it shall come to pass, when your children shall say unto you, What mean ye by this service? That ye shall say, It is the sacrifice of the LORD’S passover, who passed over the houses… and delivered our houses.” (Exodus 12:26–27)

This pattern is confirmed in the Psalms:

- “He hath made his wonderful works to be remembered” (Psalms 111:4).
- “For he established a testimony in Jacob… that they should make them known to their children” (Psalms 78:5).
- “That the generation to come might know… who should arise and declare them to their children” (Psalms 78:6).

Thus Passover is a yearly, family-taught testimony of:

- Who God is (“that ye may know how that I am the LORD” – Exodus 10:2).
- What God has done (delivered from bondage by blood and by power).
- Who God’s people are (a redeemed, separated nation).

Only those in covenant may eat of it:

> “There shall no stranger eat thereof” (Exodus 12:43).

Yet provision is made for the stranger who joins the covenant:

> “when a stranger shall sojourn with thee, and will keep the passover… let all his males be circumcised, and then let him come near and keep it; and he shall be as one that is born in the land…” (Exodus 12:48)

---

## 4. Leaven and unleavened: from outward sign to spiritual reality

Physically, Israel was to remove all leaven:

> “Seven days shall there be no leaven found in your houses” (Exodus 12:19).

God forbids leaven with the Passover sacrifice:

> “Thou shalt not offer the blood of my sacrifice with leaven” (Exodus 34:25; cf. 23:18).

In the prophets and in Christ’s teaching, “leaven” comes to symbolize a spreading, corrupting influence.

Jesus warns:

- “Take heed and beware of the leaven of the Pharisees and of the Sadducees.” (Matthew 16:6)
- The disciples then understand “that he bade them not beware of the leaven of bread, but of the doctrine of the Pharisees and of the Sadducees.” (Matthew 16:12)
- Luke records, “Beware ye of the leaven of the Pharisees, which is hypocrisy.” (Luke 12:1)

So “leaven” is used of:

- False doctrine (Matthew 16:12).
- Hypocrisy (Luke 12:1).
- Outward religion that omits “judgment, mercy, and faith” (Matthew 23:23; cf. 15:9).

Paul uses the same figure:

> “Know ye not that a little leaven leaveneth the whole lump?” (1 Corinthians 5:6)

And then he applies Passover imagery:

> “Purge out therefore the old leaven, that ye may be a new lump, as ye are unleavened.” (1 Corinthians 5:7)  
> “Therefore let us keep the feast, not with old leaven, neither with the leaven of malice and wickedness; but with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth.” (5:8)

So the physical removal of leaven in Israel symbolized and now instructs us in:

- Removing corrupt teaching.
- Rejecting malice, wickedness, and hypocrisy.
- Living in “sincerity and truth.”

This also harmonizes with the call to put off the “old man”:

> “That ye put off concerning the former conversation the old man, which is corrupt according to the deceitful lusts” (Ephesians 4:22),  
> and to “putting away lying… for we are members one of another.” (Ephesians 4:25)

---

## 5. Passover fulfilled: “Christ our passover”

The New Testament does not leave us to guess at the deeper meaning of Passover. It plainly identifies the true Passover Lamb:

> “For even Christ our passover is sacrificed for us.” (1 Corinthians 5:7)

The Passover lamb had to be “without blemish” (Exodus 12:5). Peter speaks of our redemption:

> “ye were not redeemed with corruptible things… but with the precious blood of Christ, as of a lamb without blemish and without spot.” (1 Peter 1:18–19)

Isaiah foretold of the Servant:

> “when thou shalt make his soul an offering for sin…” (Isaiah 53:10)

Psalm 22 anticipates his sufferings:

> “I am poured out like water, and all my bones are out of joint: my heart is like wax; it is melted…” (Psalms 22:14)

So Christ is:

- The spotless Lamb (Exodus 12:5; 1 Peter 1:19).
- Whose soul is made “an offering for sin” (Isaiah 53:10).
- Whose sufferings match the prophetic description (Psalms 22).

Just as the blood of the Passover lamb made God “pass over” Israel and not destroy them (Exodus 12:13,23), so believers are redeemed and spared judgment by the blood of Christ:

> “Forasmuch as ye know that ye were… redeemed… with the precious blood of Christ…” (1 Peter 1:18–19)

## 6. From Passover meal to the Lord’s Supper

The Gospels are clear that Jesus instituted the Supper at Passover:

- “And the first day of unleavened bread, when they killed the passover…” (Mark 14:12)
- “Then came the day of unleavened bread, when the passover must be killed. And he sent Peter and John, saying, Go and prepare us the passover, that we may eat.” (Luke 22:7–8)
- “Now the first day of the feast of unleavened bread the disciples came to Jesus, saying… Where wilt thou that we prepare for thee to eat the passover?” (Matthew 26:17)

In that setting, He takes bread:

> “And as they were eating, Jesus took bread, and blessed it, and brake it, and gave it to the disciples, and said, Take, eat; this is my body.” (Matthew 26:26)  
> “This is my body which is given for you: this do in remembrance of me.” (Luke 22:19)

He also takes the cup:

> “This cup is the new testament in my blood, which is shed for you.” (Luke 22:20)

Paul repeats and explains:

> “This is my body, which is broken for you: this do in remembrance of me. After the same manner also he took the cup… saying, This cup is the new testament in my blood: this do ye, as oft as ye drink it, in remembrance of me.” (1 Corinthians 11:24–25)  
> “For as often as ye eat this bread, and drink this cup, ye do shew the Lord’s death till he come.” (11:26)

So:

- The old Passover was a memorial of deliverance from Egypt (Exodus 12:14; 13:3,9).
- The Lord’s Supper is a memorial of Christ’s death and the new covenant in His blood.

As Israel all ate the lamb and identified as one redeemed people, so believers now:

> “are all partakers of that one bread” and “we being many are one bread, and one body” (1 Corinthians 10:16–17).

Paul also warns that this memorial must be approached worthily:

> “whosoever shall eat this bread, and drink this cup of the Lord, unworthily, shall be guilty of the body and blood of the Lord. But let a man examine himself…” (1 Corinthians 11:27–28)

This matches the Passover requirement that only the circumcised, covenant people could eat (Exodus 12:48).

## 7. The “golden thread” of Passover

Putting the passages together, Scripture presents a consistent picture:

1. **Passover in Egypt**  
   - God judges Egypt and its gods (Exodus 12:12).  
   - God passes over houses marked by the blood of a spotless lamb (12:7,13,23).  
   - Israel leaves the “house of bondage” (Exodus 13:3; 20:2) in haste, eating unleavened bread, the “bread of affliction” (Deuteronomy 16:3) with bitter herbs (Exodus 12:8).

2. **Passover as Israel’s perpetual memorial**  
   - Kept every year on the 14th day of the first month (Leviticus 23:5; Exodus 13:4–6).  
   - Closely joined with the seven days of unleavened bread; no leaven at all (Exodus 12:15–20; 13:6–7).  
   - Held in the place where the LORD chooses to put His name (Deuteronomy 12:5–6; 16:2,5–7).  
   - Taught diligently to children as a testimony of the LORD’s mighty works (Exodus 12:26–27; 13:8–9; Psalms 78:4–6; 111:4).

3. **Passover’s spiritual meaning: holiness and truth**  
   - Physical leaven removed from houses points to spiritual leaven of false doctrine, hypocrisy, and sin (Matthew 16:6,12; Luke 12:1).  
   - Believers are to “purge out… the old leaven” and “keep the feast… with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth” (1 Corinthians 5:7–8).

4. **Christ, the true Passover Lamb**  
   - He is the Lamb “without blemish” (Exodus 12:5; 1 Peter 1:19).  
   - His soul is made “an offering for sin” (Isaiah 53:10).  
   - His sufferings match Psalm 22 (Psalms 22:14).  
   - “Christ our passover is sacrificed for us” (1 Corinthians 5:7).  
   - By His blood we are redeemed (1 Peter 1:18–19), as Israel was spared by the lamb’s blood.

5. **The new memorial: the Lord’s Supper**  
   - Instituted at Passover (Matthew 26; Mark 14; Luke 22).  
   - The bread represents His body given; the cup His blood of the new testament (Luke 22:19–20; 1 Corinthians 11:24–25).  
   - It is a continual remembrance of His death until He comes (1 Corinthians 11:26), just as Passover was a continual remembrance of the exodus (Exodus 12:14; 13:9).

In sum, according to the KJV Scriptures given:

- Passover is the LORD’s own appointed way of marking out His people by blood, bringing them out of bondage, and calling them to a life separated from corruption (leaven) and full of remembrance.
- In the New Testament, that pattern is fulfilled and deepened in Jesus Christ, “our passover,” whose blood secures our redemption and whose death we remember in the Supper, keeping the feast now “with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth” (1 Corinthians 5:8).
